dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Conversational and analytical discussion of current events

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, Host_B, did you see the news about those expulsions? Firefighters outside, diplomats burning documents inside a compound courtyard in New York. I mean, wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, Host B, did you see the news about those expulsions? Firefighters outside, diplomats burning documents inside a compound courtyard in New York. I mean, wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: News of the expulsions featured firefighters outside the building in Houston as diplomats torched documents inside the complexs courtyard.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, right? It was, like, pure TV drama. And Senator Ted Cruz just went wild on it, calling it a "central node" for spies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, right? It was, like, pure T V drama. And Senator Ted Cruz just went wild on it, calling it a central node for spies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hardline U.S. Senator Marco Rubio proclaimed that the site was the central node in the Communist Partys vast network of spies and influence operations in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But it just makes you wonder, you know, why are we only noticing this now? Especially in an election year. And what *did* they burn?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But it just makes you wonder, you know, why are we only noticing this now? Especially in an election year. And what did they burn?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How come no one noticed until it was an election year? American spooks would like to know what documents Chinese officials burned after being ordered out of the country with just 72 hours notice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] I know! American spooks are probably dying to know what was in those, um, documents. But honestly, I'm more curious about what Biden's actual China strategy even *is*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! American spooks are probably dying to know what was in those, um, documents. But honestly, I'm more curious about what Biden's actual China strategy even is.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other Americans just would like to know what President Trumps China strategy is.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Because it feels like any long-term cooperation idea has just been thrown out the window, replaced by confrontation. Which, I mean, isn't really a strategy at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Because it feels like any long-term cooperation idea has just been thrown out the window, replaced by confrontation. Which, I mean, isn't really a strategy at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If leaders on either side of the Pacific had a long-term strategy of working together, its been thrown out in favor of confrontation. Which is not really a strategy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's not. It almost seems like we're meeting China's "wolf-warrior" tactics with, like, our own "jungle diplomacy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's not. It almost seems like we're meeting China's wolf-warrior tactics with, like, our own jungle diplomacy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. seemingly has decided to meet wolf-warrior tactics on Chinas side with jungle diplomacy on its part.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And, you know, the article mentions this whole idea that Chinese leaders are supposedly masters of patient statecraft, that "Oriental inscrutability."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And, you know, the article mentions this whole idea that Chinese leaders are supposedly masters of patient statecraft, that Oriental inscrutability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Henry Kissinger school of Oriental inscrutability peddled the canard that Chinese leaders epitomized a unique ability to conduct long-term, patient statecraft.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but Xi Jinping? He's completely thrown that out. He's not patient at all. If he *had* been, China would probably dominate East Asia in a decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Xi Jinping? He's completely thrown that out. He's not patient at all. If he had been, China would probably dominate East Asia in a decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nobody told Chinas president, Xi Jinping, or his wolf-warrior diplomats to be patient. If Xi had been more patient, much of East Asia would have been dominated by China within the next decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Instead, he's just kinda, like, goading everyone. Sinking Vietnamese boats, clashing with India... it's like he's trying to establish regional domination while the U.S. is distracted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Instead, he's just kinda, like, goading everyone. Sinking Vietnamese boats, clashing with India... it's like he's trying to establish regional domination while the U S is distracted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, he is goading countries around the region to resist China. Chinas strategy looks like taking advantage of a distracted and weakened U.S. to establish regional domination, at least. Never since the 1949 establishment of the Peoples Republic of China has the country taken on multiple enemies, as it has done this year. Whether its sinking Vietnamese fishing boats or clashing with Indian troops, China is letting the neighborhood know that its arrived.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He really is. It's such a departure from Deng Xiaoping's philosophy of "biding its time and hiding its strength." Xi's completely tossed Deng onto the, uh, "dust heap of history."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He really is. It's such a departure from Deng Xiaoping's philosophy of biding its time and hiding its strength. Xi's completely tossed Deng onto the, uh, dust heap of history.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whatever happened to Deng Xiaopings dictum that China should bide its time and hide its strength? ... Yet Xi has effectively thrown Deng onto the dust heap of history, reaching back to the past in nurturing his neo-Maoist policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And you see it in the neo-Maoist policies, too. I mean, arresting people in Hong Kong for holding up blank sheets of paper? Or you can't even joke about Winnie the Pooh without consequences.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And you see it in the neo-Maoist policies, too. I mean, arresting people in Hong Kong for holding up blank sheets of paper? Or you can't even joke about Winnie the Pooh without consequences.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its hard to see how China can build a creative and dynamic economy when people arent allowed to joke about Winnie the Pooh. The hammering of Hong Kong is yet more evidence of the urge to smother dissent that has long been common in other peripheral areas, Tibet and Xinjiang. Arresting people for holding up blank sheets of paper after threatening them under the new National Security Law, as happened in a shopping mall recently?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] It's absurd! How do you build a creative economy when dissent is so completely smothered? It just shows that desire to control, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's absurd! How do you build a creative economy when dissent is so completely smothered? It just shows that desire to control, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its hard to see how China can build a creative and dynamic economy when people arent allowed to joke about Winnie the Pooh. The hammering of Hong Kong is yet more evidence of the urge to smother dissent that has long been common in other peripheral areas, Tibet and Xinjiang.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really does. And it reminds me of that book, *The Sleepwalkers*, about Europe stumbling into WWI. This situation feels eerily similar. Like a ratchet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really does. And it reminds me of that book, The Sleepwalkers, about Europe stumbling into W W I. This situation feels eerily similar. Like a ratchet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historian Christopher Clarks The Sleepwalkers portrays a half-awake Europe stumbling into the horror of World War I. Much has been written comparing the world that Clark describes with the brewing Sino-U.S. conflict. ... Think of Sino-U.S. relations now as a ratchet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A ratchet that only goes one way, tighter. That's, um, a pretty terrifying analogy. Both sides just keep ratcheting up the pressure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A ratchet that only goes one way, tighter. That's, um, a pretty terrifying analogy. Both sides just keep ratcheting up the pressure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A ratchet only goes one directiontighter. China and the U.S. are taking turns ratcheting up the pressure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know. And you just hope nothing unexpected happens, you know, an accident. Like that incident in 2001 with the Russian pilot and the U.S. spy plane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know. And you just hope nothing unexpected happens, you know, an accident. Like that incident in two thousand one with the Russian pilot and the U S spy plane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2001 a Chinese pilot collided with a U.S. spy plane, which made an emergency landing on Hainan Island. The Chinese pilot was killed while the U.S. air crew was captured.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! That was resolved peacefully, thankfully. But, uh, I'm not sure we'd be so lucky today, are you?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! That was resolved peacefully, thankfully. But, uh, I'm not sure we'd be so lucky today, are you?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That dramatic incident was resolved peacefully. Its hard to believe that we would be so fortunate today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [sighs] No, Host_B, I really don't think we would. It's a very different world now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, Host B, I really don't think we would. It's a very different world now.
